page.title: 19KILBURN AREA:DENBY POTTERY
page.content: The pottery was founded by Joseph Bourne in 1809.Clay was found during the construction of a road and Bourne found it to be of good quality.Rather than have it taken to his Belper factory,he built a few huts on the site at Denby. The clay is thrown and wheeled, or put into a mould.Then it is jolleyed (spare clay wiped off)by a lady,as a man's hands are too clumsy.Then the pots are dried in a warm room,being turned regularly for evenness.The pots are then fired until they become a biscuit colour.After that,they are sprayed and dipped into coloured glaze before being fired for a second time. They are then hand-painted or else transfers are put on to them.They are then fired again,packed and then despatched.Imperfect pots are sold in the popular Denby Seconds Shop.
